Dear Amanda Waidelich:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth woke up around 3:45am stating not feeling well. Youth had
a headache and body trimmers and asked for medication to sleep
better. A staff member gave youth Ibuprofen medication. The
youth can't have Ibuprofen because youth is on Lithium. Staff
member didn't check the medication log because staff was unable
to get to it. At 7am in the morning, another staff member started
shift and noticed the error and then reported it to the social
worker. The on-call nurse was then made aware of the incident.
Staff was asked to then monitor youth to make sure youth didn't
have any reactions to the Ibuprofen. Youth is fine, and didn't
sustain any behavior changes or injuries from this incident.
Investigation Interviews:
Clinical Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility
on February 18, 2025. Clinical Supervisor reported he was on-
call over the weekend. He reported on February 15, 2025, at 7 am
he received a phone call from Staff 2 stating Youth A was
provided an incorrect medication from Staff 1 overnight. Clinical
Supervisor reported he was informed Youth A was provided
Ibuprofen for a headache overnight which he cannot have due to
being on Lithium. He reported Nurse was in contact right away
and Youth A was monitored. Due to the low dose of Ibuprofen,
Youth A was monitored and showed no concerning side effects.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 18, 2025. Youth A reported he is recovering from not
feeling well over the weekend. He reported when he does not feel
well, he asks the staff for medicine to help with his cold and fever.
Youth A reported over the weekend Staff 1 and Staff 2 provided
him his medication. He reported he remembered one night over
the weekend when he woke up in the middle of the night and
asked Staff 1 for medication for a headache. Youth A reported
Staff 1 provided him with Tylenol and he went back to bed. He
reported that Tylenol made him feel a lot better. Youth A reported
staff always checks medication with the computer to make sure he
is getting the correct medications. He reported feeling safe at the
facility.
2

Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on February 19, 2025. Staff
1 reported she is an on-call worker for the facility but has been
employed there for six years. She reported she has been trained
in medication passing but has had difficulty logging into the Quick
Mar system. Staff 1 reported this is normally not an issue because
she does not pass medication on the third shift. She reported
working the third shift with Staff 2 from February 14, 2025, to
February 15, 2025. Staff 1 reported Youth A had woken up around
3:45am stating that he was not feeling well and had a headache.
She reported she looked around for Staff 2 since she could not log
into the Quick Mar system, but Staff 2 was not on the unit. Staff 1
reported she waited a little bit, but Youth A was getting drowsier,
so she just provided him with two tablets of Ibuprofen. She
reported she saw Staff 3 a few moments later and asked her to
log the medications she provided to Youth A. Staff 1 reported
around 6 am, Staff 3 asked her again what medication she
provided Youth A so that she could log it, and Staff 1 told her two
tablets of Ibuprofen. She reported Staff 2 came onto shift at 5 am
and was working with Staff 3 on medications. Staff 1 reported
Staff 2 informed her that Youth A cannot have Ibuprofen due to
this not being on his approved medication list. She reported she
felt horrible about the situation. Staff 1 immediately reported this
medication error to Clinical Supervisor and Nurse. She reported
the proper protocol for passing medications is for staff to check
the Quick Mar system to make sure the medications are approved
but she failed to follow that protocol. Staff 1 reported she should
have waited for Staff 3 to provide the medications as she did not
have access to Quick Mar to verify the medication.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on February 24, 2025. Staff
3 reported she worked the third shift with Staff 1 from February 14,
2025, to February 15, 2025. She reported Staff 1 oversaw
medications on shift that night but was unaware that Staff 1 could
not get access to the Quick Mar System. Staff 3 reported at one
point during the night she went to the cafeteria to grab something
and when she returned to the unit, Staff 1 had asked Staff 3 to log
a medication for Youth A. She explained that Staff 1 could not get
her access to work in the Quick Mar system, so she asked Staff 3
to log that she had provided Youth A two tablets of Ibuprofen.
Staff 3 reported she did not end up logging the medication and
asked Staff 2 to do this task when she came onto shift at 5 am.
She reported that was when Staff 2 stated Youth A did not have
Ibuprofen approved on his medication list and Nurse was
contacted. Staff 3 reported the protocol for passing any
medication to a youth is that staff are supposed to check the
computer system for the approved medication before providing
3

any medication. She reported this is because the youth’s
medications are always changing, and it is a safety risk if this is
not completed correctly. Staff 3 reported she has never had any
concerns about working with Staff 1 and believes this was not an
intentional error as Staff 1 just wanted to help Youth A feel better.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on February
18, 2025. Staff 2 reported she worked on February 15, 2025, and
started her shift at 5am. She reported Staff 3 informed her that
medication needed to be logged for Youth A as he had a
headache overnight. Staff 2 reported she was informed Staff 1
provided Youth A two tablets of Ibuprofen overnight which is not
on Youth A’s list of approved medications due to being on Lithium.
She reported that she called the on-call Nurse and contacted the
Clinical Supervisor because Youth A was being given a non-
approved medication. Staff 2 reported Nurse informed her to
monitor Youth A’s signs and noted that he did not need further
treatment at this time as he was presenting with no concerns.
When asked about the process of providing medication to the
youth, Staff 2 reported only medication-trained staff are to pass
medications. They are then to log into the Quick Mar computer
system and pull up the youth’s chart. Staff are then to get the
medications only listed on the Youth’s Quick Mar list and make
sure to mark them as given. Staff 2 reported when she talked to
Staff 1 about this situation, Staff 1 took full responsibility for
passing the wrong medication. She reported Staff 1 explained she
could not get into the Quick Mar System and wanted to help Youth
A’s headache.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on February
18, 2025. Nurse reported she was contacted by Clinical
Supervisor on February 15, 2025, of Youth A taking a non-
approved medication. She reported she was informed Youth A
was provided Ibuprofen overnight for a headache when he is only
allowed to have Tylenol. Nurse explained Youth A cannot have
Ibuprofen because he is on Lithium and the Ibuprofen can
increase his toxicity levels. She reported due to Youth A just
having a low dose and not showing any concerning symptoms,
she directed staff to monitor Youth A for the day and to call if there
were any concerns. Nurse reported she did check in on Youth A
and there were no concerning symptoms. When asked about
proper medication protocol she reported staff are directed to log in
to Quick Mar and make sure to double-check the appropriate
medications are being provided to the youth. She reported Youth
A only has Tylenol listed as medication that would help with a
headache.
4

Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Incident Report dated February 15, 2025,
completed by Staff 1- Staff 1 wrote in this incident report
Youth A woke up complaining of a headache and asked for
pain medication to help. Staff 1 noted she was not able to
log into his med chart and administrated 2,400 mg of
Ibuprofen tablets. She asked Staff 3 to log the medications
for her. Around 7am when Staff 2 arrived for her shift, she
was alerted Youth A cannot have Ibuprofen due to being on
Lithium. Nurse was contacted and Youth A was monitored.
- Youth A’s Medication list- Youth A’s medication list has
Tylenol listed as an approved as needed medication.
Ibuprofen is not listed as an approved medication.
- Human Resource File for Staff 1- Staff 1 had two
disciplinary actions noted within her file. In January 2024,
Staff 1 was provided verbal coaching due to not completing
the required training hours with the year end of 2023. In
November 2018, Staff 1 refused to stay over on her shift
when her peer called off, she was provided a written
warning due to ratio concerns. Staff 1 is up to date on all
required trainings with her most medication training being
completed on March 15,2024.
- Human Resource File for Staff 3- Staff 3 has no
disciplinary actions noted within her file. Staff 3 is up to
date on all required trainings including most recent
medication training on November 21, 2024.
- Health Services Policy and Procedure- This policy states
all medication-trained staff will administer medication in
accordance with Medication Administration and Control
Policy.
- Medication Administration and Control Policy- This
policy states staff are to prepare one youth’s medications at
a time. Prepare medications carefully, using the six rights of
medication (right medication, in the right dose, at the right
time, by the right route, for the right person, and the right
documentation). Staff are to positively identify the youth
served using two identifiers (name, photo, date of birth,
confirming with familiar staff) before medication is
administered.
- Medication and Adverse Reactions Policy- This policy
states a medication error is defined as any error that occurs
in the transcription, administration, and/or documentation of
medications. If an error is made, employees should
5

acknowledge any error, and assess the consumer by taking
vitals, completing a visual assessment, and making
required notifications. Nursing will assess and provide
further instruction, as needed. Incident report is required to
be completed.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as Staff 1 confirmed she
did not follow the facility’s medication procedure as she did not
verify Youth A’s medications prior to giving him the medication.
This caused Youth A to take medication that is not allowed to take
due to the other medications he is on.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR2025SIC0000112 dated 12/12/24, CAP Approved 1/6/24
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
